Bluff – oder: Nur für die Mensa. Das Spielprinzip ist wahrscheinlich so alt, wie Würfel selbst. Wer wettet richtig, welche Würfel liegen? Die ewigen Bierzeltgarniturspieler:innen werden gleich an „Mäxchen“ denken. Dieses hat noch den Vorteil, dass man nicht nur Würfel verliert, sondern auch noch einen Schnaps trinken muss. Aber mal ehrlich: Spiele unterliegen ja dem persönlichen Geschmack. Wer also gerne ein bisschen zockt, ist mit Bluff sicher gut bedient. Richtig Erfolg in Gruppen hatte ich damit aber nie auf dem Spieletisch beim Spieleabend, sondern nur in der Mensa. Mal eben zwischen den Seminaren und Lehreinheiten ein bisschen gewürfelt und gezockt. Und hinterher mit freigepustetem Hirn zurück in den Unterricht. Als Spiel zum Auftakt oder Ende eines Abends unterliegt Bluff der Mode: Es gibt Neueres und Besseres, Kürzeres oder Kleineres. Kommunikativ ist es nicht, weil man ja immer nur die nächste Wette mithört und nicht antwortet. Und all das macht es eben zu einem hervorragenden Spiel für die kurze Pause in der Mensa. Wenn man die völlig unnötige Verpackung zu Hause lässt, passt das Spielmaterial auch in jeden Rucksack. Bei welcher Gelegenheit und für welche Zielgruppe es sich anbietet, hat sich uns nicht erschlossen. Es hat jedenfalls sonst nie jemand gefragt: „Können wir bitte Bluff spielen?“ Decken wir Bluff mit einem der schwarzen Becher zu!

It's silly how much worse this is than Mia and Skull.

Pros:
Sometimes the dice surprise you and give you a laugh.

It's basically a free game many people already have lying around.

Cons:
The player elimination is pretty bad, and can lead to players sitting out for quite a long time. You also get less info the more hits you take, so there's a fall away loser issue of spiraling into having less and less fun.

Above all, I don't think the game rewards or encourages bluffing. The way to bluff in this game is to throw out a random number that isn't well-represented under your cup. This has several issues:

1: Since the bids rarely go several circles around the board, this may be your one chance to add information to the group and you may not want to take any risks doing this since the punishment may be to sit out for 30 minutes!

2: Since you have so little information about all other players other than their bids, you can't tell if your bluff is meaningful or affects anyone. For example, if you know that someone else has a lot of threes, it could be fun to say that you also have threes to try to trap them! But you have no way of knowing that, so why even bother?

3: You don't actually get anything for calling out a bluff, you can win the game without ever calling and just betting well. This incentivizes playing safe and not really playing the game for as long as you can!

4: Sometimes you don't have a hand that's easy to bluff with. If you roll a bunch of wilds, nothing you say will be a bluff and if you only roll 5s, why bet on anything else that you have no info on?

Also, there's no way to affect any player but the ones next to you, so the game doesn't feel interactive and the only benefit to more players is that the dice distribution becomes more interesting.

The biggest con to this is that Mia and Skull exists. Mia is better because everyone has the same information so bluffing is more interesting, also the way I play it means that dice carry over, which usually leads to an escalating bluff going out of control, which is fun. Skull is better because it's much faster and has a different end condition that rewards risk-taking, plus you have much more control over how you want to bluff.

BGG's standards for the boundaries of individual games never fail to make me grunt a bit. As I write these words, anything called "second edition" seems to get automatically granted its own new entry (splitting the forums, comments, reviews, ratings etc.) regardless of any significant change made to the game; but earlier in the history of the database, the opposite and equally baffling extreme was the norm.

Here are Dudo/Bluff/Liar's Dice/Perudo, titles deemed similar enough to be a single game entry. According to BGG, that game is simultaneously public domain, born in the 19th century, has the very 20th century Richard Borg as its designer and has won the Spiel des Jahres in the early 1990es. My first interpretation of this was that Borg had managed to repackage an old public domain game (maybe changing a minor rule in the process) and pretend he designed it himself. Reality is however more complicated than that. After the admittedly minimal amount of research I could be bothered to do, here's my understanding of the history of Perudo:

• Dice games involving cups and bluffing had some level of popularity in South America in the 19th century. One of them may or may not be close enough to modern Perudo, but there is to my knowledge zero historical evidence of it.
• Richard Borg iterates on a traditional dice game he names Liar's Dice, realises he can't make money from it unless he repackages it with additional components, and adds a board after witnessing that the bidding structure is the only part new players have trouble with.
• Liar's Dice is published in 1987 and wins the Spiel des Jahres in 1993. This inspires other similar traditional games to borrow good elements from it. One of these games, Dudo, is rebranded as Perudo to hint at a Peruvian origin.
• Enthusiasts and publishers bend and/or make up facts about Perudo's origins in order to reinforce the exoticism and traditional roots of the game. The Wikipedia page of the game has basically no reliable source, each paragraph of perudo.com's history of the game starts with "it is believed that", and sellers of (hand-made) Perudo sets are too happy to overplay the modern mythology surrounding the game.
• Someone reads that Perudo is an old game, doesn't fact check and adds 1800 as its date in the BGG database.

So in short, and until proven wrong, I'll consider that Richard Borg is to be credited for the initial design. I'll also consider that so many variants got published without any backlash that you can make your own copy for cheap without feeling like you're ripping Borg off.

4 plays:

Spectacularly addictive, competitive, and thrilling. My group exploded with gasps and groans every 5 minutes, and after finishing a game immediately started another.

Players do get eliminated, but the game tightens and gets quicker as fewer players (with fewer dice) are left, so it doesn't feel boring on the sidelines.

Rules are fairly simple, and then strategy emerges naturally from there, with many wrinkles and opportunities for clever and Machiavellian play.

Consistently a big hit -- there are very few better games in terms of the ratio of complexity to intense, competitive joy.

Game complexity/weight: 2 out of 5

Up-rating from a 5 to an 8, really enjoyed it at a lower player count where it felt like there was more control.

Up-rating to a 9 after a few more plays. Such a simple game that is almost at the level of Cockroach Poker for bluffing, fun and laughter.

With the right group, this game sings and deserves a 10 rating
